participants.participant: Nils Vinge, Head of Investor Relations

plist.p: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the presentation of Hennes & Mauritz Full Year Report Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in listen-only mode until we conduct the question-and-answer session. And just to remind you, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to hand over to today's chairperson Nils Vinge, Head of IR. Please begin your meeting and I will be standing by.
Thank you. Hello everyone, and welcome to this telephone conference on the occasion of H&M's full-year and fourth quarter results.

The presentation slides are found on our website, hm.com. Our CFO, Jyrki Tervonen and our Head of Communications, Kristina Stenvinkel, are with me today and we will answer your questions after the presentation.
Before moving on to the fourth quarter, I'd like to make a brief comment on the start of our new financial year.

Sales in December and thus far in January have been satisfactory. The positive development should of course be seen in the light of easy comparables particularly for December and the fact that sales have been partly markdown driven.
That said, we also note that our earliest Christmas collections have been well received.
In December, sales including VAT increased 16% in local currencies and comparable unit sales increased 3%. From 1st to the 26th of January sales increased 13%, compared to the same period last year.

Please turn to the slide fourth quarter 2009. Sales in the quarter excluding VAT reached 28 billion, an increase of 6% in Swedish kroner and 3% in local currencies, however with great differences between the various markets.
Sales in comparable units decreased 6%. Sales were negatively affected by restrained consumption in most markets due to continued economic recession and the fact that the market was discount driven.
The autumn was unseasonably mild, which had a negative effect on sales of weather dependent sales such as jackets and heavy knitwear.

Gross profit increased 13% to 18.6 billion, corresponding to a gross margin of 66.3%, compared to 62.4% last year. The currency hedging of the market on internal sales to the subsidiaries had a positive effect on the gross margin of 120 basis points, compared to a negative effect of 150 basis points in the fourth quarter 2008.

Among other things, the gross margin was also positively affected by greater surplus capacity at suppliers, more efficient buying process and year-end effects mainly related to lower shrinkage than estimated.

Increased markdowns had a negative impact on the gross margin of around 50 basis points. Following a review of our currency hedging policy, we've chosen to end the hedging of internal mark-ups with effect from 1st December 2009.

Forward contracts maturing in the first half year have already been entered. This means that the majority of the internal mark-up for the first quarter is currency hedged, which is expected to have a positive impact on the gross margin based on current exchange rates.
The effect will diminish gradually in the second quarter and disappear thereafter. We've also decided to apply currency hedging for 100% of our flow of goods instead of as previously 90%.

H&M maintained a good cost control also in the fourth quarter. Selling and administrative expenses were 10.7 billion, up 11% in Swedish kroner and 9% in local currencies, compared to the fourth quarter of the previous year, despite an expansion of as many as 148 new stores net.

We successfully countered the effect of the recession by keeping a tight rein on costs and adjusted our store operations to the current market situation. Costs in comparable stores decreased from last year. Operating profit for the quarter rose 16% to 7.9 billion corresponding to an operating margin of 28.2%. Profit after financial item reached close to eight billion, a rise of 12% from the year before.

Net profit increased to just about 6.1 billion corresponding to earnings per share of 7.44 kroner. Sales, excluding VAT, rose to about 101 billion, an increase of 15% from the year before. Including VAT, sales increased 14%. In local currencies the increase was 4%. Comparable unit sales decreased 5%. Gross profit was 62.5 billion and the gross margin increased 10 basis points to 61.6%. We maintained a good cost control throughout the year, keeping sales and administrative expenses low, despite the largest expansion in number of stores in the history of H&M thus far.

Costs were 40.8 billion, compared to 34.3 billion a year before. The operating margin was 21.3% in the year of weak sales developments. Net financial items amounted to 459 million, a reduction by half, compared to the previous year and the direct result of lower interest rates. Still, profit after financial item rose by close to one billion to 22.1 billion.

With a new reduced Swedish corporate tax rate, the tax rate for the Group was 25.9%. Profit after tax rose 7% to 16.4 billion, corresponding to earnings per share of 19.80, compared to 18.48 the year before. The recession increased the supply of good store locations in 2009 and made it possible for H&M to sign more contracts than originally planned and at favorable terms. Therefore, we opened as many as 250 stores net, considerably more than the 225 planned at the start of the year.

In the fourth quarter alone we opened 159 new stores. The majority of the openings took place in Germany, UK, the U.S., France and Italy. We closed 11 stores. H&M is now present in 35 markets with 1,988 stores, of which 36 franchise at the end of the quarter.

Germany, our by far largest market with sales of more than 30 billion Swedish kroner and 262 stores for the full year, continued its solid and profitable growth. In contrast, the situation in the three large markets, the U.S., Spain and France was tough last year.
We continue our expansion in these markets, however, and see many new and exciting opportunities for H&M.

In France, we opened 21 new stores during the year and refurbished a large flagship store on Boulevard Haussmann. In Spain, we opened 15 new stores and although sales development in comparable stores was weak, profitability was . In the U.S., we opened 20 new stores during the year and refurbished the Fifth Avenue flagship store. The first stores in Florida and Arizona opened during the year.

Sweden developed well last year with sales up to – up 10% in the autumn. Meanwhile in the UK, the development was decent with higher sales in local currency, a weak earning however had a negative impact on profitability and growth translated into SEK.

China and Japan both had a good year. We entered China only two and half years ago and opened our first stores in Japan, a little more than one year ago. Sales reached 2.7 billion Swedish kroner in these two countries combined last year and our expansion continues.

China is among the markets where we are expanding the most number of stores already in 2010. After the successful start in Russia last spring, sales continued developing well. At the end of 2009, we had four stores in Moscow and one in St. Petersburg.

And now some – a few words on some key figures. The stock-in-trade increased 20% to 10.2 billion, compared to the same time the previous year. Approximately half of the increase was due to the expansion and the remaining part mainly due to the weak sales during the autumn.

As sales were weak during the fourth quarter, the stock-in-trade for the 30th of November contains a larger proportion of mainly weather dependent garments compared to the same time a year before. This will lead to larger markdowns during the first quarter 2009, 2010, compared to the first quarter of last year. In relation to sales, the stock-in-trade was 10.1%. Historically, it's still a good level.

Cash flow from current operations was approximately 18 billion, about the same level as the year before. Investments amounted to 5.7 billion kroner, which is a lower level per store than the year before. 2010 investments are expected to reach slightly more than six billion.

Our finances remain very strong, liquid funds and short-term investments were 22 billion. The Board of Directors will propose at the Annual General Meeting a dividend of 16 kroner per share corresponding to 81% of net profit for the year. Return on equity was 42.2%, compared to 44.3 last year.

H&M maintains a very positive view on the opportunities for future expansion. Our target remains to increase the number of stores by 10 to 15% per year and continue to drive profitability. We plan to open around 240 stores net in 2010. The plan includes 12 COS stores and 25 new Monki and Weekday stores. The expansion will take place in all our markets, with the majority of the openings in the U.S., UK, China, France, Germany and Italy.

We are opening our first store in South Korea on the 27th of February in Seoul. We view South Korea as an exciting market that offers great potential with its many fashion interested people and its strong purchasing power. We see good growth potential also in our other large Asian markets, China and Japan.

Israel will become a new franchise market this spring. Moreover, we will expand our Internet sales to the UK in the autumn of this year. This will also make H&M Home available to our British customers. The development of COS, Monki and Weekday is going according to plan. This spring, we will open the first Monki and Weekday stores in Finland and the first Monki store in the Netherlands in Amsterdam.

Looking ahead, finally, we want to say that despite tough market conditions, we delivered strong results for 2009. Clearly, we were not happy with the sales development during 2009. And even though sales in the first quarter of 2010 has started well, we focus strongly on our target to increase sales in comparable units with continued high profitability.

Experiences that we have gained during the recession are of great value for us, as we continue working for further improvements. We are looking at all parts of our business, everything from assortment mix, logistics and marketing to store design and how we display our garments. We are increasing efficiency in our buying and production processes, which will generate gains that we will invest in order to further improve our customer offer. This may involve lower prices, but it could also mean more fashion and quality at the same price.

We still look at our markets with great respect for the economic development. And our strong business concepts has proven profitable, also at times of tough market conditions. We will continue to expend to new markets and see room to grow in existing markets, as well as to develop our new formats COS, H&M Home, Monki and Weekday.
Thank you for your attention. And we're now happy to take your questions. Hello?
Hello. Would you like to begin the question-and-answer session?
Yes, please.
Our first question comes from the line of Karen Howland from Barclays Capital. Please go ahead ma'am.

Good afternoon. I was wondering – I mean the gross margin improvement obviously was very impressive, the 400 basis points. I know you talked about the hedging being a positive 120, the markdown being negative 50, so netting about 300 or so. That's I guess buying and/or additional sourcing capacity.

I was wondering if you could give some color as far as, is that sustainable? If we should expect that same sort of improvement going forward or if this was somehow a one-off this quarter that shouldn't be repeated in the next quarter? And how you actually were able to get those sort of a benefit – those sort of benefits and the magnitude of benefits that we saw? Kind of one question.

Yeah. As you mentioned, the main components affecting the gross margin in the fourth quarter was the internal hedging of the mark-ups. And of course there are other things with a positive effect like surplus capacity of the suppliers and also some efficiency to the increased efficiencies in our own buying processes. And also, there is year-end effect, which is relating to the shrinkage. It was less than we have been calculating for during the year. So, of course we don't want to go into more detail when it comes to our own measures that we have done. For competitive reasons, we want to keep that for ourself.
But the efficiency improvement, there is no reason to think that this was any sort of a one-off that would be this quarter. It should continue going forward?

Yes, we believe that some of the efficiency things we have done in the buying process will continue. But of course, as we've many times said, there are so many different factors affecting the gross margin. So, there are positive things and negative. So, of course we think that these efficiencies we have done will remain.
Thanks. I'll get back in the queue.
Our next question comes from the line of Richard Chamberlain from Bank of America. Your line is now open.

Thank you, afternoon gents. Congratulations on the strong quarter. I just had a question on the – on your inventory position at the end of the year. How much of the 20% increase was related to currency and how much to expansion effect, please?
Currency effect on the stock-in-trade at the year-end, it's around 1%. And as Nils said it – the half of the increase approximately is due to expansion.
Half due to expansion. Okay, thanks very much.
The next question comes from the line of Peter Farren from Bryan, Garnier. Please go ahead.

Yes. Hi. So, then my one question will be on the quantification of the internal hedging impact on the gross margin assuming that FX rates as they are today, if you could quantify the Q1 and the Q2 impact, please?

We don't want to quantify it in absolute figure or a percentage. But with the current exchange rates, we are estimating that the effects will be positive in the first quarter this year and a little bit less positive in Q2, and then they will be done.

Okay. Can I have a quick another one, if I don't have an answer. It's on the CapEx. You're guiding for six billion for 2010, which is higher than 2009, yet you're opening a lower number of stores and the FX should be a little more favorable. Is there any explanation for that?
Well in the CapEx, it's not just the store openings, there are other things as well in the CapEx such as strategic investments in IT et cetera.
Okay. So, they will increase, okay.
The next question comes from the line of Fraser Ramzan from Nomura, London. Please go ahead ma'am.

Hi, there. Yes, could I ask a question about the long list of improvements you said you were going to be continually making to your offer? I think you said assortment, logistics, marketing, design, buying efficiencies, reinvestment in price, quality and fashion.
Impressive, isn't it?

I mean, of course, I'm sure you're always busy working on those, but clearly in some of your key markets, like the U.S. last year, your like for like was down more than I think might be just purely explained by the economy. So, what should we expect to see happening in your stores?

And I appreciate you don't make big step changes and everything is incremental in part of the mix and all that kind of thing. But do you feel you need lower prices in some places and is that significant enough that you actually want to make a comment about it like you have today? Or do you feel – and do you feel you really do need perhaps a slightly higher proportion of fashion in some places? And I appreciate it's a quantum, it's a continuum, and you're always doing these things, but you went to a great length to list, lots and lots of things you thought might be defected with your offer at the moment.

It was a long question. But, yes, I can confirm that we look at all the – all of those things always actually. But of course in a weak year like this, we put even more focus on improving the customer offer, and that could of course vary from market to market. And if you strip out the pricing, that is of course very important and in some markets it's more important than others. But we will invest in even a stronger offering to the customer and that is already – you can see it already in the stores today.
The next question comes from the line of Robert Miller from Redburn Partners. Please go ahead ma'am.

Yes, good afternoon. It's actually on a similar theme. Can you tell us what your price positioning is relative to last year going into the new season and particularly in some of these new markets where you've been – you've underperformed the local market particularly badly like France and Spain?
Well Robert, we don't give any guidance going forward when it comes to pricing. We don't want to give that out to the competitors. But I promised you that we --
I see your prices, Nils.
Yes, but why tell them in advance?

Okay. In which case, can I ask you a different question relating to costs? Your average number of full-time employees was basically flat year-on-year which is an astonishing performance given the amount of physical growth in the company. Can you tell us a bit about what the phasing was of the significant like for like reduction in employees and what the outlook is therefore for 2010?

As we have mentioned, we have a good cost control in our comparable stores and also we have been talking about the flexibility we have in planning the staff hours in our stores. And this is simply relating to that we are using a lot of extra staffs for weekends, evenings, peak selling periods, et cetera. And of course with this weak sales development that we have had that we haven't had the same need for those hours.
Okay. So, it's fair to assume that it was weighted broadly with the degree of weakness in your like for like sales through the period?
Yes.

Yeah. And do you think that going back to your predecessors often guidance that cost to sales ratio of 37 to 38% was sensible for your business. Do you think the business is headed back to that ratio in the near term? Do you have a ?

We have had a lot of focus on the ratio. And as we have said, we have a really good cost control and we are confident that we will work really good with our cost in the future as well. And as you see in absolute figures, the increase in SG&A expenses is purely relating to the expansion and in comparable stores we have decreased the expenses. So, of course it's also – yeah, a matter of top line. If the selling is with us, so of course the ratio will look better.
The next question comes from the line of Fred Bjelland from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead ma'am.

Hi, good afternoon. My question is quite similar to Robert's. It's – basically you've now had two consecutive years of decent gross margin expansion, yet your EBIT margin is going down, and I think you're touching on the OpEx ratios. But is there a certain level of like for like that you think is necessary to get operating leverage back in the model? And presumably, if the gross margin stays at similar levels, I mean where – when would you expect to get that kind of operating leverage through?

It's a very difficult question. We don't look at it really that way, but I mean we always try for a positive like for like, and this year unfortunately we haven't succeeded. But if we do that, I'm sure we will continue to grow in a profitable way.

And going back to the OpEx, even a situation with tough conditions, we can present a strong result. So we are not focusing so much on the ratios when it comes to OpEx. We have a good cost control and --

Okay. I mean it's a fairly generic answer. But I mean ultimately over the last three years you've delivered like for likes of five minus one and minus 5%. And in – so it's basically not just an economic conditions problem, I mean the cost to sales ratio has gone up in every single one of those years, both in good and in bad years. And I was just wondering, is there more cost you can take out or do you think that this ratio will continue to worsen? Or do you – is it purely a matter of the like for like getting back up?

I think, of course, that the best way is to get up the like-for-like figures and we're always planning to get it up, but still I think we have the flexibility in a situation like this to handle good profitability.
Okay. No, there's no doubt about that. Thank you very much.
The next question comes from the line of Anne Critchlow from SG. Your line is now open.

Hello there. Going back to the underperformance in U.S. and France and Spain, and but also thinking about expansion into newer markets, for example the Far East. I'm just wondering is there any plans to differentiate the ranges between countries a bit more. And I think traditionally you had about 80% of the range coming through all countries. Is that still the case?

Yes, it's around 80%, 80 to 85%. But it is something also that we are looking into to have a more – even more customized collection absolutely. But there is always a balance of that and efficiency. But among other things, yes.
And is there a particular focus on, say, the underperforming countries in that respect?
No, not really.
Okay, thank you.
The next question comes from the line of John Guy from MF Global Securities, sorry. Sir your line is now open.

Yes, and good afternoon gentlemen. Could you just let us know if your numbers of suppliers have changed at all, and obviously you alluded to significantly better buying. I was just wondering if there have been any significant change over the course of the year? That's the first question.
No significant changes, but I think that our long-term relationships to the suppliers pays off.

Okay. And if I could just have a follow-up with regards to timing and estimated cost for an Asian distribution platform. I know this is something that we've talked about in the past, it's something you don't have at the moment, but I assume that you are planning to put in a distribution platform in Asia at some stage?
Could you clarify exactly your question for the other listeners please?

Well, yeah I was just asking and I asked the question I think during the last call with regards to investing in Asia and the rollouts in Asia. And I'm just trying to get a feel for whether or not you'll be putting in a centralized distribution platform in Asia?
Okay. No, no, there are no such plans to date.
Okay. Thank you very much.
The next question comes from the line of Andrew Hughes from UBS. Your line is now open.
Hello, yeah, Good afternoon, gentlemen. Can you hear me?
Yes, good afternoon.
Yeah, just checking.
Sound check.

Sound check. Yeah, the question I have again is on gross margin in the first quarter. I know that you don't want to comment on the scale of the benefit from the internal hedge. But is that going to be – do you think higher or lower than the markdown impact?

There are a number of different factors that drives the gross margin, where currency is one and where markdowns is another and source increases is third. So, some of them will be positive and some of them would be negative, but to give you a guidance of the total gross margin I refrain, so I am sorry.
No, I don't mind about the total gross margin. Can you give me a comment on just those two specific items?
The markdowns would clearly be, have a negative impact compared to last year in Q1. And the second one was --?
The internal hedge?
Internal hedge will be positive, given the current exchange rates.
Should we assume they're roughly the same scale?
Sorry again, no we don't quantify it. We give you the – it is positive because it could change if the currencies change.
Okay. And on the sale --
Sorry, I should remind you that last year there was a very big negative effect on the currency hedges and the non-hedged part as you remember.
Yeah. Yeah. I mean on like-for-like in the first quarter you are positive after the first two months. Is that all the effect of clearance or do you think underlying like-for-like is positive?
It is a combination. There is a clearance, yes, clearance effect. But there is also the first collection, spring collections have also been doing well.
So, the positive like-for-like isn't just the clearance?
No.
Isn't just the clearance effect. Okay. Thank you.
The next question comes from the line of Tony Shiret from CS. Your line is open.

Hi, guys. A bit of a lower expectation of an answer here, but try anyway. I just wondered you're talking about the, stopping the internal hedge mechanism. I wondered whether that was related in anyway to a change in the internal markup behavior that you engage in? I note that nearly 80% of your operating profit is booked in group functions in 2009. Are you going to reduce the level of markup that you put on product before you set it on to the regional companies? That's the question.

Yeah. The transit pricing model would continue as it has been since we introduced this in 2007, so that will be the same. It's only the internal hedging of the markup as we are reaching a strong December 1.
Do you not – does it not worry you maybe that this is contributing to your sales performance in the regions? Are you passing on prices to the subsidiaries that are too high?
No, not at all.
Any evidence to support that? The sales don't seem to support it.
That doesn't really has to do with the price that we take to the consumers' internal markup.
Yes. This internal markup has nothing to do with the pricing in the local markets.
Okay, thank you very much.
The next question comes from the line of Luca Solca from Bernstein. Please go ahead.
Hello.
Hi.

I see that you have an imported number of stores for the non-H&M brand earmarked to open in 2010. Could you give us an idea where you stand on the concept development for these new formats on COS, on Weekday and Monki? And whether you feel that they are actually ready for an international rollout and they are mature for that, or whether you're still in some cases experimenting and fine-tuning the concepts?

Yes. As we start with COS, we follow the defined objectives and are satisfied with the development, but we do not comment more into detail. But we do have 23 stores, COS stores today in five, six different markets, and in 2010 we plan to open another 12 COS stores. So, I think that answers some of your, perhaps worries about, yeah, new COS.

Regarding FaBric, today we have 46 Monki and Weekday stores. When we acquired FaBric Scandinavien we had around 20 stores, and we have more than doubled and we have started to roll this out internationally. We plan to open around 25 Weekday, Monki stores this year. And new markets, as I said, will be Finland and the Netherlands. And finally H&M Home, we launched it this spring, or last year and it sold well. And we wouldn't – and we opened the first H&M store or showroom in Stockholm and it has been very well received. We now look for additional opportunities to roll out stores in the group.
And may I follow up on this, are you planning any designer collaborations on these stores too, and what is in the pipeline in this respect for the H&M brand going into 2010?
There were two questions. The first question was if we have any collaborations, is that it?
Yes, yes. Either for H&M or for the other brands that you have in the pipeline.
We have a lot of plans but I don't think I am going to give you all the details, we want to surprise the customer.
Thanks for that. Thank you.
Yeah, of course we have the Sonia Rykiel very soon, if that's what you are referring to, the Sonia Rykiel designer collaboration with H&M.
Right, yes, yeah.
Yeah.
The next question comes from the line of Yurk Anavitsky from Textivertsa. Your line is now open.
Good afternoon I have a question regarding the German market. Can you tell me something about the like-for-like development in Germany? And then also what is the percentage --?
Sorry one question at a time, please.
Okay.
So first question regarding Germany, we are quite satisfied with development in Germany, could of course be better, but we don't comment on like-for-likes in certain markets.
But it's a plus figure?
Again sorry.
Okay. What is the percentage of the Internet and catalog sales on the total business in Germany. Can you give me a figure for that?
I am very sorry but those are exactly the kind of questions that we don't answer for commercial reasons. So – but we are quite happy with the development in Germany, and throughout the company.

All right, one more please. The H&M Home is that going to be like owned stores or are you planning on further showrooms or like because there is a difference between a showroom and then owned stores, like are you – will you open new owned stores this year?
Look at many different possibility. We don't rule out anything but we are looking for physical stores where customers can look and feel the products.
So not stores in shops or shop in shops, like owned stores?
As I said, we don't rule out anything.
Okay. All right.
The next question comes from the line of Karen Howland from Barclays Capital. Please go ahead ma'am.

Thanks so much for the follow up. I was wondering when you look at – I mean your gross margin obviously, a significant improvement, I think it's the highest across retailers globally right now. How do you weigh that gross margin improvement with your pricing? Because I mean your sales obviously were quite weak, begun to see some stabilization now. But, the negative 5% like-for-like for the quarter, coupled with this significant improvement in the gross margin, I guess how do you weigh between giving that back to customer to shy that out of sales, versus maintaining the margin for yourself?

Our goal is always to grow with maintained or continued high profitability. We do – I must emphasize that we do have a very good pricing positioning today and a good offer. But we will invest in even better offering in the future.
Thanks.
The next question comes from the line of Simon Owens from BRM Capital. Your line is open.

Hi, question about how you take stock provisions at year end? I mean you obviously came into year-end with excess stocks, at the time you were starting to discount. And I was wondering how you value your stock knowing that you're going to have to discount that stock to get it out over the next couple of months say?
Yeah, the valuation in the – for the stock in trade is to purchase price.
Right so you take no advance provisions against stock at year-end regardless even of when – even if you've effectively already sold it at a lower price to your valuation?
Yeah, but we are not selling it under purchase price. And according to --
Right.

...the regulations we have to evaluate the stock either to the purchase price or a lower price. But of course we are having the purchase price, and if you are referring to make some kind of accrual for obsolete stock, if you are referring to that, that we can't do.
Right. And when did you start your promotions? Did that actually start across the board in December or was that just in the UK?
Well we have run promotions continuously as well. But of course there is always a more focus towards the end of each season.

Okay and if I could just ask a follow up. In terms of your buying conditions I was intrigued by your comment that buying conditions have effectively improved which is unusual halfway, effectively in the second half of the collection. I mean did they improve later on in the year or was that pretty much there all the way through autumn, winter?
It's been good throughout the year but a slight improvement towards the end.
Okay, thank you very much.
The next question comes from the line of Richard Chamberlain from Bank of America. Your line is open.

Thanks a lot. Yeah, thanks for taking the follow up. Just a follow up on Simon's point there, I wondered if you are seeing really any signs of any sort of supplier pricing pressure coming through. I mean obviously the dollar has weakened a little against the kroner in recent months and are suppliers now starting to push back a little bit and demand better terms in response to that?

It looks pretty good so far but of course in the long term when economy comes back again, I'm sure we will see prices and cost come up. But again I think due to the long-term relations we have with suppliers, we still have very good – good terms.

Right and presumably excess capacity as well. And then just on a – a follow up again on gross margin, you talked about the currency hedging, the mark-up on sales of goods to the subsidiaries having a 120 basis point positive impact on gross margin. Was there a significant currency effect from the dollar-kroner exchange rate, particularly on the unhedged portion of the buying in dollars?
The effects on the unhedged 10% approx effect was immaterial – insignificant.
Insignificant, okay. Thanks.
The next question comes from the line of Fraser Ramzan from Nomura. Your line is open again. Hello, the line of Fraser Ramzan is open.
Hi there. Sorry thanks for taking the follow up. Quick one on December and January local currency sales, could you say what they were at full price, please?
Sorry in, ?
Yeah, full price sales in December and January. Because you have given a total number, but obviously you've said the markdowns were a factor this quarter.
Sorry. No, no. We gave you – this is the figure we gave you. We are sorry.
Yeah of course it's a combination, as we mentioned, about a combination of full price but also reduced garments.
Okay. Perhaps I could ask a follow up then. Could you quantify the impact of shrink on the fourth quarter gross margin, the better than expected shrink position?
Yeah, the impact is around half a percentage unit. Somewhere 50 to 60 basis points.
50 to 60 bps. Okay. Thank you very much.
Welcome.
The next question comes from the line of Philip Mitchell from Nomura. Your line is open.

Yes. Hi, just a very quick question to do with some anecdotal stories I have been hearing in terms of availability in the store of a product that you advertised on your posters, obviously the quite aggressive pricing that you advertised. Are you happy with the availability of the product that you actually advertised? Is it something that's changed over the last two years or so? And sort of a follow-on to the same question is whether you are getting frustrated by the fact that so many other companies seems to be copying this method of advertising now and whether that may in fact cause you to change the way in which you advertise?
I'm sorry, I don't really – the first question was availability of products, was that it?
Availability of products that are specifically advertised in your poster campaigns.

Yeah, of course. And sometimes we really want to have even higher quantities. So, yes, sometimes we are selling them out really quick. And of course in those situations we always want to have even more to sell. That's quite natural.
There is no difference.
Yeah.
This year compared to any other year, even though we always of course strive to find the right quantities.
Quantities, yeah.

And the next question regarding competitors. I mean I think this is part of the game that everyone is inspired of each other and tries to improve, so that's nothing new either. But we always try to improve, as we said before, in every part of the Group.
Okay. Thank you.
The next question comes from the line of Rolt Colve from Omen Equity. Please go ahead. Your line is open.
Hi, Rolt here. Regarding your suppliers, specifically in China, would you say that the excesses in Q4 is less than it was earlier in 2009?
I would say it's more or less on the same level, the surplus capacity in Q4 as it has been in Q3 and Q2.

Okay. My second question regarding your expansion in Russia. Some of your competitors have encountered some problems with customs and timing of store openings, that kind of issues. Have you had any of these problems?
No, we haven't had any problems when it comes to customs or other things as well. So, we are really happy with the expansion in Russia. So --
Okay. My final question regarding your expansion in the U.S. Is it still focused on large cities or are you looking more at regional expansion?
It's mostly in large cities. Definitely.
The next question comes from the line of Robert Miller from Redburn Partners. Your line is open.

Hi. Just thinking about your investment program in the existing store base. I think it was 2006 when you pretty much stopped investing in refurbs, because you weren't happy with the new format. So, could you tell us what proportion of the estate you have upgraded since then so in the three years?

It's true that we didn't stop, but we made a say half halt and then we increased dramatically quite a lot and we've been at around 100 and plus that in the last couple of years since. So, three, 400 stores roughly that had major refurbishment. Then of course in old stores we do small uplifts continuously.

Because the – I suppose the reason for the question is the 300 stores or so in the context of the Group is not very much. Has the focus of that been on flagships? And is the -and is there any reason to suggest that in the market where you've done particularly badly you think it could reflect under investment in your space?

I don't think we've under invested in space in the last years. Perhaps if you go back five, six, seven, eight, nine years ago, we might have – if you look back, we could have invested more. But I wouldn't agree that we've under invested the last three years.

And I think the plus 100 per year is quite a good level for refreshing up our stores. And of course with the high expansion rates we have had in the past years, the stock or the portfolio of stores are quite new, when for instance, during 2009, 250 new stores.
. The next question comes from the line Peter Farren from Bryan, Garnier. Your line is now open.
Hi, again. Just a clarification. Do you intend to reinvest all of your buying related gains this year into lower prices or higher fashion?
I understand your question, but I'm sorry I don't think we will tell you or the competitors that. But we will invest lot of money into the customer offer, absolutely, to improve it even further.
Okay. Thank you.
The next question comes from the line of Andrew Hughes from UBS. Your line is open.

Yes. Hi, again. I had a question on the space component, which in the couple of months of the New Year seems to have flipped up to 12%. Is that just a timing issue or are we starting to see some of the areas where you're opening proportionally more stores, like Japan actually contribute more to sales for each new store opening?

Well, it is a combination of many things and we have been discussing this space conversion for a while and people love to see trends in some direction. And as we say, this could vary up and down depending on where we open and what kind of stores were opened, and this is exactly what it reflects. So, I'm sorry, I can't give you any trend. But I agree it looks better beginning of this year so far.
And of course there are also some timing issues.

Yeah. On the topic of timing issues, I suppose looking back at last year you had a couple of periods when in August you were short of stock and then November you had too much stock. Is that a function of primarily weather or is it how you adapt to the downturn, or is there something else in terms of logistics issues within the group which is making it more difficult to control stock levels?

Well, I think we've become even better than ever to control the inventory, but it is – to run retail business is quite difficult. I don't know if you've tried it. So, even though we have some problems – I mean it's still all in all we are very happy and the quarter is very profitable as you've seen.

But there are no – any logistic issues behind it. For instance, the level of the stock in trading and November its mainly due to that we are heavy on the weather dependent garments like jackets and heavy knitwear.
Okay. Thank you.
The next question comes from the line of Tony Shiret from CS. Your line is open.

Yeah, hi again guys. I don't know if you've answered this actually. ASPs, can you tell us what your ASPs were in the autumn, winter season, full price ASPs? And can you tell us where you started off the current season year-on-year?
Again, Tony sorry, one question at a time please. First question was ASP right?
Yeah.
On comparable items, it was same prices. And ASP is slightly up due to mix.
And slightly in your terms is what, sort of low single digits or one or 2%? Is it slightly up sort of less than five or --?
Yeah. One to two marginally.

Okay, sorry. I am going to ask second question because everyone else has been anyway. Just on this, sorry, coming back to the transfer of pricing that I discussed with you earlier, have you not had any – do you have to get some sort of tax agreement with the tax authorities in the countries that you trade in? Just surprised that people sort of agreed to let you write the profits into Sweden where you've got a lower tax rate, nice for you. But I am surprised that some of the other tax authorities don't think that's a bit of money out of their pocket.

Yes, of course we have had a lot of talks with different tax authorities in different countries and, of course in some countries it's, yeah, as you mentioned it's kind of an agreement than in other countries. It's just a discussion and we're trying to give them a picture how our transfer pricing model is done. So, yes, we are having discussions with the local tax authorities.
How do you sort of justify the fact that you make most of your profits in Sweden when you got sort of relatively small portion of your sales there?

Yeah the basic is of course that the creation of the value is here in Sweden where we have the buying office, the design, the head office and buying office functions. And so, the creation of the value is clearly in Sweden.
So the creation of 80% of the value in Hennes & Mauritz is in the buying office in Sweden. Is that what you sort of argue to them?
Yeah, more or less.
Seems odd, doesn't it. Okay. Thanks.
The next question comes from the line of Nicklas Fhärm from SEB Enskilda. Your line is open.

Thank you. I just wanted for the record to ask you on the buying margin. Have you – have there been any structural changes, specifically within the sourcing that are sort of sustainable? To give you a hint to my question, for example, have you changed the actual mix of the countries you actually source from?
No, there are no big changes and they're always continuously as fashion changes and et cetera. But no, nothing worth mentioning now regarding sourcing.
So, there are no structural changes. So when the cycle turns, you will just incur the full impact of the higher pricing when capacity utilization drops?
But we said Nicklas that they were not just capacity utilization, they were also efficiency gains in the sourcing and in buying production. And those helpfully are more of a structural matter or -
Sustainable.
Yeah. Sustainable, if you want.
Okay, thank you.
The next question comes from the line of Erik Karlsson from AKO Capital. Your line is open.
Thanks for taking my question. You mentioned the good reception of the spring collection. Just how would you compare the reception of this spring collection compared to that of last year's?
Better.
Thank you.
Okay.
No further questions are registered at this time. I'll hand the conference back to you.
Thank you very much for participating in this long conference call. And welcome back for our first quarter results on the 8th of April.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation today. This concludes today's conference. And you may now disconnect your lines. Thank you very much and good-bye.
